titleStmt.title: Persons and groups named in the Homeric poems
Homer
titleStmt.author: Gabriel Bodard
Argyro Moulavasili

person.note: hero of the Iliad, leader of the Myrmidons (part of Achaeans army), son of Peleus and Thetis
King of Mycenae, son of Atreus, leader of Achaean forces, brother of Menelauscommonly called wide ruling, mighty
son of Telamon, leader of forces from Salamis, greatest Achaean warrior after Achilles, known as the Great Ajax or the Greater Ajax
son of Oleus, leader of Locrian troops

son of Thestor, priest and interpreter of omens for Achaean army: responds to Achilles in assembly (1.73 ff); interprets Apollo's anger (1.98); abused by Agamemnon (1.110); Odysseus tells of C.'s original prophecy about how long the war would last (2.350); Poseidon takes on his form to rally Achaeans (13.48).
son of Tydeus, King of Argos, a younger (but major) warrior with Achaeans

mortal child of Zeus, wife of Menelaus and later of Paris (Alexander): mentioned by Hera (2.187); mentioned in catalogue of ships (2.667); visited by Iris in form of Laodice, while she is weaving (3.135); Helen visits the walls of Troy, talks to Priam (3.153 ff); observed by Trojan elders (3.168); looks for her brothers (3.260); forced by Aphrodite to go home to Paris (3.434 ff); returns home to Paris, talks to him (3.468 ff); at home with Paris, speaks to Hector (6.396 ff); Antenor proposes giving her back (7.404); Achilles detests her (19.397); laments over Hector's body (24.936).
son of Deucalion, leader of Cretan forces, a major senior commander in the Achaean forces
son of Atreus, brother of Agamemnon, first husband of Helen of Troy, King of Sparta, major figure in Achaean leadership
King of Pylos, senior warrior among Achaeans, called the Geranian horseman
son of Laertes, father of Telemachus, King of Ithaca, major warrior for the Achaean forces, commonly called resilient and resourceful and cunning
son of Menoetius, an Achaean warrior, special comrade of Achilles
son of Menoetius, an Achaean warrior, special comrade of Achilles

bastard son of Telamon, an Achaean warrior: kills Aretaon (6.36); returns to battle, kills Orsilochos, Ormenus, Ophelestes, Daitor, Chromius, Lycophontes, Amopaon, Melanippus, praised by Agamemnon (8.312 ff); complains how hard Hector is to hit (8.341); kills Gorgythion (8.353); kills Arkheptolemos (8.363); wounded by Hector (8.380); goes with Telamonian Ajax to help Menestheus (12.407); wounds Glaucus with an arrow (12.425); moves to attack Sarpedon, hits him with an arrow (12.441 ff); encouraged by Poseidon as Calchas (13.104); kills Imbrius (13.198 ff); kills Prothon and Periphetes (14.602); collects the best troops to fight Hector (15.359); kills Cleitus (15.519); Zeus breaks his bow string, he complains to Ajax (15.541 ff); enters the archery contest (23.1058).
major Trojan warrior, leader of Dardanians, son of Anchises and Aphrodite

senior Trojan councilor, father of Archilochus, Acamas, Helicaon, Iphidamas, Laodocus, Pedaios, Polybus, Agenor, Laodamas, Demoleon, and Con: at the Scaean Gates with Priam, comments on Helen (3.159); story of his welcoming Odysseus, description of Menelaus' and Odysseus' speaKing (3.222); goes with Priam to the armies (3.293); returns with Priam (3.350); advises Trojans to give back Helen (7.404).

son of Hippolochus, leader of Lycians (Trojan allies): in Trojan display of forces (2.960); moves out to fight Diomedes, tells story of his family (6.146 ff); Zeus steals his wits (6.298); kills Iphinous (7.13); one of the leaders in the assault on the wall (12.107); told of the warrior ethic by Sarpedon (12.332); wounded by Teucer (12.425); helps defend wounded Hector (14.498); hears Sarpedon's dying words, prays to Apollo for restored strength, Apollo answers, rallies Lycians, urges Hector to avenge Sarpedon (16.572 ff); kills Bathycles (16.691); urges Hector to fight harder to avenge Sarpedon (17.188); encouraged by Hector (17.289).
son of Sisyphus, father of Bellerophon (6.193).
leader of Trojan forces, son of Priam and Hecuba
son of Priam and Hecuba, brother of Hector, abductor of Helen from Menelaus

son of Panthous, Trojan warrior: preparing for battle (11.59); advises Hector on tactics to assault the ditch (12.61); one of the leaders in the attack on the wall (12.92); with troops in perplexity by the ditch (12.204); advice to Hector to withdraw in face of Zeus' omen (12.220); advises Hector to attack with best men (13.861); goes with Hector and others to the centre of the fight (13.936); rallies around wounded Hector (14.497); kills Prothonor, boasts about it (14.523 ff); stops horses of dead Cleitus (15.531); kills Mecistus (15.399); kills Otus (15.610); attacked by Meges, saved by Apollo (15.611); wounds Peneleus (17.731); advises returning to the city, warns what happens if Achilles returns to fight, criticized by Hector (18.305 ff).
King of Troy, husband of Hecuba, father of Hector and numerous others

son of Zeus and Laaodamia, leader of the Lycians, Trojan allies: in Trojan display of forces: (2.960); complains of Hector's treatment of allies (5.558); challenged by Tlepolemos, kills him (5.733 ff); wounded in the thigh (5.767); appeals to Hector (5.788); has spear removed (5.800); story of his birth (6.255); leads allies in assault on the wall (12.106); stirred to action by Zeus (12.315); speech to Glaucus on the warrior ethic (12.332); upset at wounding of Glaucus, keeps fighting, kills Alcmaon, pulls down a section of the parapet (12.431 ff); hit by an arrow from Teucer, withdraws, calls to his Lycians (12.441); helps defend wounded Hector (14.498); Zeus foretells his death (15.82); rallies Lycians against Patroclus, goes against him, gods decide he must die, fights, hits one of Patroclus' horses, and dies (16.489 ff); dying words to Glaucus (16.571 ff); struggle over his body (16.657 ff); condition of his body in the fight (16.744); body taken by Apollo, given to Sleep and Death, put in Lycia (16.790 ff); his armour set up as prize for hand to hand fighting (23.985).
father of Odysseus: mentioned by Athena (2.202).
son of Odysseus: mentioned by Odysseus (2.307).

relation.desc: mistress and love interest of Achilles

person.note: daughter of Briseus, captive awarded to Achilles: Agememnon threatens to take her away (1.201); heralds fetch her from Achilles (1.369 ff); story of her capture by Achilles (2.761); (9.128); Agamemnon offers to return her, swears he hasn't had sex with her (9.158); Achilles wishes she'd been killed (19.70); returned to Achilles, Agamemnon swears he has not had sex with her (19.303 ff); laments over the corpse of Patroclus (19.344); sleeps with Achilles (24.834).

relation.desc: taken as a war prize by Agamemnon

person.note: daughter of Chryses, captured by Achaeans: Apollo's anger that she's not ransomed (1.15); Calchas says she must be given back (1.104); Agamemnon refuses to give her back (1.119); Agamemnon proposes expedition for her return (1.154); led on board ship for return (1.345); Achilles tells story of her capture (1.409); taken to Chryse, reunited with her father (1.481 ff).

person.occupation: goddess of love, beauty, and sexual pleasure
person.note: divine daughter of Zeus and Hera, goddess of erotic love: mother of Aeneas (2.901); rescues Paris from Menelaus in their duel (3.407); tells Helen to visit Paris, threatens Helen (3.427 ff); rescues Aeneas from Diomedes (5.367); wounded by Diomedes, asks Ares for his horses, leaves the battle (5.390 ff); complains to her mother, who heals her wound (5.442); Hera summons her, asks her for a love charm, she agrees (14.224 ff); Zeus tells Hera to summon him (15.66); leaves Olympus to help the Trojans (20.49); leads wounded Ares from the battle, attacked by Athena, collapses (21.500 ff); protects Hector's corpse (23.223).
divine son of Zeus and Leto, supports Trojans in the war
son of Zeus, Olympian god of war (especially the destructive aspects)
goddess daughter of Zeus, strong supporter of the Achaeans
divine wife and sister of Zeus, daughter of Cronos

divine son of Zeus, called "killer of Argus": receives royal staff from Zeus, passes it on to Pelops (2.119); rescued Ares (5.460); love for Phorbas (14.571); had sex with Polymele, fathered Eudorus (16.215); leaves Olympus to help the Achaeans (20.43); opposes Leto in battle (20.84); declines to fight with Leto (21.600); gods urge him to steal Hector's body (24.25); instructed by Zeus to guide Priam to Achilles, sets off to meet Priam (24.412 ff); meets Priam and Idaios, reassures them (24.446); takes over Priam's chariot, takes him to Achilles hut, putting guards to sleep (24.546); reveals his identity to Priam (24.566); wakes Priam up to take him back to Troy, leaves him (24.837).

divine messenger of the gods: sent by Zeus to Trojans to get them to organize themselves, speaks to Priam (2.864 ff); visits Helen in form of Laodice (3.135); drives Ares' horses taKing Aphrodite back to Olympus (5.431); Zeus sends her to intercept Hera and Athena (8.463 ff); takes message from Zeus to Hector (11.211); Zeus tells Hera to summon her (15.66); Hera tells her to go to Zeus on Ida, she does so, Zeus tell her to take message to Poseidon (15.173 ff); goes to Poseidon, persuades him to leave the battle (15.201 ff); sent by Hera to rouse Achilles (18.205); delivers Achilles' prayer to the winds (23.239); leaves Olympus to summon Thetis to Zeus, returns with her (24.97 ff); instructed by Zeus to visit Priam and tell him to visit Achilles (24.177); reaches Troy, speaks to Priam, leaves (24.199).

person.occupation: god of the sea and earthquake
person.note: major Olympian god, brother of Zeus

most powerful of the gods, common called "the son of Cronos," "cloud gatherer," "lord of the lightning bolt," "aegis bearing," brother and husband of Hera, father of numerous gods: mentioned in the invocation (1.6); Agamemnon claims a special relationship with Z. (1.194); story of Zeus' being saved by Thetis from other gods (1.439); returns from Ethiopians, visited by Thetis, agrees to grant her request to help Achilles (1.549 ff); threatens Hera if she keeps pestering him (1.627); goes to sleep with Hera beside him (1.685); worried about how to deal with Thetis' request, sends Dream to Agamemnon (2.1 ff); receives royal staff from Hephaestus, passes it on to Hermes (2.118); Agamemnon blames Zeus for their lack of success (2.130); Odysseus tells of his serpent omen eating birds and being turned to stone (2.362 ff); omens when Achaeans set out to sea (2.415); refuses Agamemnon's prayer (2.494); special favours for people of Rhodes (2.743); sends Iris to organize Trojans (2.865); declines sacrifice of Achaeans and Trojans for a truce (3.340); in assembly of gods, provokes Hera (4.2 ff); agrees to break truce, instructs Athena to see to it (4.83); tells Aphrodite to stay away from battle (5.508); tells Athena to chase Ares from the battle (5.874); appealed to by wounded Ares, chastises him, blaming Hera (5.994 ff); steals Glaucus' wits (6.298); answers Poseidon's objection about Achaean wall (7.530); plots bad things for troops (7.555); tells gods not to intervene in the war, boasts of his strength (8.4); responds to Athena, leaves Olympus for Ida (7.44 ff); holds up his golden scales, result favours the Trojans, sends thunderclap (8.77); sends a lightning bolt to stop Diomedes (8.153); peals thunder three times to stop Diomedes (8.195); gives glory to Hector (8.250); pities Agamemnon, sends bird omen to the Achaeans (8.287); puts renewed force into Trojans (8.391); Athena complains about his favours to Thetis (8.430); angry and Zeus and Hera, sends Iris to stop their visit to the battle (8.463 ff); returns to Olympus from Ida (8.510); reveals his plan to glorify Hector and Achilles (8.549); Agamemnon complains of his deceit (9.19); punishes Phoenix (9.574); sends Strife to Achaean ships (11.3); send down rain of blood (11.54); gazes at the battle (11.85); pulls Hector back (11.186); goes to Ida, send Iris with order for Hector (11.208 ff); looks from Ida onto battle, makes the contest equal (11.382); makes Telamonian Ajax afraid (11.615); put power into Pylians (11.864); helps to destroy Achaean wall in future (12.27); desires to give Hector glory (12.181); omen sent to soldiers (12.209); Zeus sends winds from Ida to disorient Achaeans (12.270); stirs Sarpedon to action (12.315); gives glory to Hector (12.482); turns away from the battles (13.3); aat cross purposes with Poseidon (13.418); reaction to being deceived by Sleep over Hercules (14.292); seduced by Hera on Mount Ida (14.345 ff); list of his various sexual encounters (14.377); wakes up on Ida, sees wounded Hector, berates Hera, reminds her of her earlier punishment, tells her the future of the war (15.4 ff); sends Iris with orders for Poseidon to leave the battle, boasts of his strength (15.186 ff); division of power in his family (15.224); instructs Apollo to restore wounded Hector (15.266); hears Nestor's prayer, sends a thunder clap (15.446); breaks Teucer's bow string (15.541); strengths Trojans, weakens Achaeans (15.694); neutralizing Ajax's strength (16.147); hears Achilles' prayer (16.298); pities Sarpedon, agrees he must die, sends blood rain (16.504); spreads darkness over the battle (16.661); ponders options, takes Hector's courage (16.750 ff); tells Apollo to take Sarpedon's body to Lycia (16.775); gives Patroclus desire to fight (16.802); gives Hector Patroclus' (Achilles') helmet (16.927); responsible for a warrior's courage (17.227); observes Hector putting on Achilles' armour, fits armour to Hector, fills him with strength (17.256); helps Achaeans defend Patroclus' body (17.348); makes battle over Patroclus destructive (17.502); pities Achilles' horses in mourning for Patroclus, refuses to let Hector have them, gives horses strength (17.546 ff); shakes aegis, peals thunder, awarding victory to Trojans (17.723); responds to Ajax's prayer, removes mist from Achaeans (17.790); conversation with Hera about Achilles' return (18.443); Agamemnon blames him for quarrel (19.107); once deceived by Ate (19.117 ff); threw Ate from Olympus (19.156); Agamemnon prays to him, swears he has not had sex with Briseis (19.315); pities Achilles, tells Athena to give him strength (19.414); asks Themis to call assembly of gods, lets gods join the war (20.6 ff); thunders in the battle (20.67); once rescued Aeneas from Achilles (20.110); his love for Dardanus and hatred for Priam (20.364); Achilles appeals to him for help to escape the river Scamander (21.327); laughs to see the gods fighting amongst themselves (21.467); consoles Artemis after Hera beats her (21.610); watches Achilles chasing Hector, considers sparing Hector, sends Athena to intervene (22.206); raises his scales, determining Hector's fate (22.260); refuses to permit Hermes to steal the body of Hector, sets up a compromise, calls for someone to summon Thetis (24.78); instructs Thetis to tell Achilles to compromise over Hector's body (24.127); instructs Iris to visit Priam, tell him to go to Achilles to get Hector (24.177); hears Priam's prayer, sends an omen, instructs Hermes to guide Priam (24.392 ff); description of his two jars of gifts (24.650); turned people to stone (24.758).
son of Eussorus, leader of the Thracians: in Trojan display of forces (2.925); Ares takes on his form (5.548); killed by Telamonian Ajax (6.109).

son of Antenor, Trojan warrior: in display of Trojan forces (2.905); helps prepare troops for battle (11.62); one of the leaders in the assault on the wall (12.104); kills Promachus, boasts aloud, withdraws (14.553); killed by Meriones (16.400).
father of Menoetius, grandfather of Patroclus.
King of Sicyon: in catalogue of ships (2.648); father of Aegialeia (5.490); his fine race horse Arion (23.423).
son of Bucolion and Abarbarea: killed by Euryalus (6.30).
river flowing near Troy from Mt. Ida to the sea: (2.908); stirred up by Apollo and Poseidon to destroy the wall (12.22).
son of Ancaeus, leader of Arcadian troops (part of Achaean forces): in catalogue of ships (2.686).

son of Antenor, father of Echeclus, Trojan warrior: kills Elephenor (4.542); helps prepare troops for battle (11.61); one of the leaders in the attack on the wall (12.96); Aeneas calls him for assistance (13.591); helps wounded Helenus (13.711); helps defend wounded Hector (14.497); kills Clonius (15.401); incited by Apollo to fight Achilles, debates his options, fights Achilles, rescued by Apollo (21.658).
son of Aesyetes and Hippodamia, Trojan warrior: one of the leaders of the assault on the wall (12.97); killed by Idomeneus (13.514).
Achaean warrior, attendant on Achilles (perhaps the same as Alcimedon): helps prepare Achilles' chariot (19.472); helps unload the ransom for Hector (24.712).
Trojan warrior, son of Merops, leader of troops from the Troad: in list of Trojan forces (2.912); killed by Diomedes (11.375).
son of Selagus, Trojan warrior: killed by Telamonian Ajax (5.717).
Achaean warrior: killed by Hector (5.713).
father of Aeneas (a Trojan warrior): had sex with Aphrodite (2.901); gets his mares pregnant from horses of Tros (5.318); conceives Aeneas with Aphrodite (5.370); his family tree (20.286).
father of Echepolus (Achaean warrior).

wife of Hector, daughter of Etion: not at home when Hector visits (6.454); meets Hector by the Scaean Gate (6.480); tells the story of the slaughter of her family by Achilles (6.504); returns home (6.604); feeding Hector's horses (8.216); learns news of Hector's death (22.546 ff); predicts her son's fate (22.602); goes to meet Priam returning with Hector, laments over Hector (24.875).
PATRONYMIC
son of Nestor
father of Hippolochus and Peisander: advised Trojans to kill Menelaus (11.153).
Trojan warrior: killed by Leonteus (12.198).
one of the Boeotian leaders: in the Achaean force (2.570); killed by Hector (15.389).

relation.desc: brother of Acamas, son of Antenor

person.note: son of Antenor, Trojan warrior: in the display of forces (2.904); one of the leaders for assault on the wall (12.103); killed by Telamonian Ajax (14.540).
father of Menesthius (Achaean warrior): called the Mace-man, killed by Lycurgus (7.163).
Trojan warrior: killed by Achilles (20.585).
Trojan warrior: goes with Aeneas and Hector to fight Automedon (17.611); killed by Automedon (17.637).
human son of Ares, Achaean warrior, leader of Minyans: in catalogue of ships (2.587); leads out the sentinels (9.101); Idomeneus calls him for assistance (13.575); killed by Dephobus (13.623).
Trojan warrior, brother of Hecuba, Hector's uncle: Apollo takes on his form (16.835).

son of Hyrtacus, leader of troops from Troad (part of Trojan forces): in Trojan display troops (2.918); one of the leaders in the assault on the wall (12.99); refuses to follow tactics of Polydamas (12.115); killed by Idomeneus (12.122 ff); vexation with Zeus (12.170).
Trojan warrior: challenges Idomeneus, is killed (13.467).

son of Hector and Andromache, an infant, also called Scamandrius: Hector meets him and Andromache at the Scaean Gate: (6.487); afraid of his father in armour (6.572); Andromache predicts his fate (22.602).

son of Diores, Achaean warrior: prepares Patroclus' chariot and horses (16.175); clears tangle of Patroclus' horses (16.551); tries to rouse Achilles horses (17.535); fights from a chariot without a weapon, brings on Alcimedon, attacked by Hector (17.569 ff); prays to Zeus, receives strength, calls for help to the Ajaxes (17.614 ff); kills Aretus (17.635); evades Hector's spear (17.645); strips armour, boasts aloud (17.657); helps prepare Achilles' chariot (19.472); deals with Priam's cart and bring in the ransom (24.712); sets out bread for Achilles and Priam (24.776).
son of Teuthranus, Trojan warrior: killed by Diomedes (6.14).
father of Sisyphus.
son of Phradmon, Trojan warrior: killed by Diomedes (8.301).

goddess, daughter of Zeus and Hera, sister of Apollo: taught Scamandrius to shoot (5.56); helps to restore Aeneas (5.530); killed Laodamia (6.262); killed Andromache's mother (6.522); incites Aetolians and Curetes to fight (9.667); invoked by Achilles (19.71); leaves Olympus to help the Trojans (20.48); opposed by Hera in battle (20.81); angry with Apollo for not fighting Poseidon, beaten by Hera (21.566); seeks consolation from Zeus (21.609); her slaughter of Niobe's daughters (24.750).
one of Achilles' horses (16.180; 19.480).
one of Achilles horses (16.180); talks to Achilles (19.486).
one of Hector's horses (8.213).
son of Phaenops, Trojan warrior: killed by Diomedes (5.174).

river outside Troy, also called the Scamander, also the god of the river: leaves Olympus to help the Trojans (20.49); opposes Hephaestus in battle (20.86); Achilles kills men in the river (21.20 ff); river gets angry at Achilles' slaughter of Trojans (21.164 ff); calls to Achilles to stop the slaughter (21.252); cries out to Apollo about Achilles' conduct (21.275); attacks Achilles (21.284); calls to his brother to help against Achilles (21.371); burned by Hephaestus, agrees to stop fighting Achilles, appeals to Hera (21.427 ff); springs feeding the river (22.184).
from Odyssey
an Achaean warrior leader serving with Nestor: receives his orders (4.347).
Achaean warrior, one of the leaders of Athenians: fighting against Hector (13.824).
father of Laogonus and Dardanus (Trojan warriors).
Trojan warrior:killed by Diomedes (6.21).
son of Clytius, Trojan warrior: killed by Telamonian Ajax (15.491).
father of Aphareus (Achaean warrior).
daughter of Priam, wife of Orthryoneus: (13.442); sees Priam and Idaios arrive, calls out to the city (24.860).

priest of Apollo, father of Chryseis: insulted by Agamemnon (1.12 ff); prays to Apollo for revenge (1.38); reunited with his daughter, prays to Apollo to lift the plague from Achaeans (1.490 ff.); sacrifices to Apollo (1.513).
one of the Boeotian leaders in the Achaean force; in catalogue of ships (2.571); killed by Agenor (15.401).
son of Laomedon, brother of Priam, senior Trojan statesman: with Priam at the Scaean Gates, observes Helen (3.162); father of Caletor (15.491); his family tree (20.284).
father of Dolops (Trojan warrior).
Trojan warrior: killed by Odysseus (5.784).
Achaean warrior: saves Idomeneus, killed by Hector (17.744).
Trojan priest of Hephaestus, father of Phegeus and Ideus: (5.10).

relation.desc: in intimate relationship with Achilles before the Trojan War

person.note: son of Priam, Trojan warrior: one of the leaders for the assault on the wall (12.97); steps forward to challenge Achaeans, struck by Meriones, withdraws (13.182 ff); challenges Idomeneus, kills Hypsenor (13.488); seeks out Aeneas to fight Idomeneus (13.546 ff); Aeneas calls to him for assistance (13.591); throws spear at Idomeneus, hits Ascalaphus (13.621); strips helmet from Ascalaphus, wounded by Meriones in the arm, withdraws from battle (13.633 ff); Athena takes on his shape to trick Hector (22.281); cursed by Priam (24.312).
daughter of Phrobas: captured by Achilles from Lesbos, sleeps with him (9.840).
son of Eumedes, Trojan warrior: volunteers for spy mission to the ships (10.376 ff); runs away from Diomedes and Odysseus, is caught, provides information, is killed by Diomedes (10.417 ff).

relation.desc: grandson of Zeus (and son of Minos)

person.note: father of Idomeneus, son of Minos: (13.541).
Trojan warrior: killed by Achilles (20.573).
Achaean warrior: killed by Hector (7.11).
father of Rhesus.
son of Chalcodon, commander of the Abantes, part of Achaean forces: in catalogue of ships (2.613); killed by Agenor (4.537).
leader of the Mysians, Trojan warrior, an interpreter of omens: in Trojan display of forces (2.940); death from Achilles mentioned (2.942); encouraged by Hector (17.281).
Trojan warrior: killed by Odysseus (11.481).
son of Agacles, Achaean warrior : his story, killed by Hector (16.666).
son of Panopeus: enters the boxing contest and wins (23.822 ff); enters the iron-throwing contest (23.1032).

goddess active in war, sister of Ares: accompanies Ares and Athena into battle (4.513); active on the battle field (5.612); leads Trojans, helping Hector (5.696); depicted on the aegis (5.845); sent by Zeus to Achaean ships, stands by Odysseus' ship, lets out a yell (11.3 ff); pleased at the killing (11.77); depicted on Achilles' shield (18.659); in action in the battle (20.57).
son of Polyidus, Achaean warrior: comes to Troy knowing his fate, killed by Paris (13.791).
son of Jason and Hypsipyle: sends wine to Agamemnon and Menelaus (7.545); paid ransom for Lycaon (23.920).
son of Troezenus, leader of Ciconian troops (Trojan allies): in display of Trojan forces (2.927).
son of Panthous, Trojan warrior: his skills as a soldier, wounds Patroclus (16.936); calls to Menelaus, is killed by him (17.11).

a senior leader of the troops from the Argolid, son of Mecisteus, an Achaean warrior: in catalogue of ships (2.643); kills Dresus, Opheltius, Aesepus and Pedasus (6.23); enters the boxing contest, his triumph at the funeral games of Oedipus (23.837); knocked almost unconscious (23.853).
one of the Achaean heralds: sent by Agamemnon to collect Briseis from Achilles (1.360 ff); picks up Odysseus' cloak (2.215); proposed for delegation to visit Achilles (9.209).
Trojan priest, father of Abus and Polyidus (Trojan warriors): (5.171).

son of Euaemon, leader of troops from parts of Thessaly (in Achaean army): in catalogue of ships (2.808); kills Hypsenor (5.86); kills Melanthus (6.42); volunteers to fight Hector (7.201); returns quickly to battle (8.311); stands by Telamonian Ajax, kills Apisaon (11.648); wounded by an arrow from Paris, withdraws, calling out to Achaeans (11.657); meets Patroclus, assisted to his hut (11.937); tells Patroclus the Achaeans are doomed (11.951); Patroclus leaves him (15.460).
King of Cos (2.750).
Trojan warrior: killed by Agamemnon (6.38).
divine daughter of Oceanus: helped Hephaestus (18.502).
son of Priam and Castianeira, a Trojan warrior: killed by Teucer (8.353).
Trojan allies: in display of Trojan forces (2.938).

relation.desc: she was given as a captive to King Nestor

person.note: daughter of Arsinous, given to Nestor after Achilles' sack of Tenedos: attends on Nestor and Machaon (11.702).

wife of Priam, mother of Hector (and others): meets Hector, gets instructions to sacrifice (6.315); prays to Athena with Trojan women (6.377); sees Hector isolated outside the wall, begs him to come inside (22.99); lament at sight of dead Hector (22.506 ff); opposes Priam's proposed trip to Achilles (24.249); tells Priam to make an offering to Zeus before setting out (24.350); comes out to meet Priam with Hector's body, laments over Hector (24.875).

son of Priam, reader of omens for Trojans: advises Hector on strategy (6.89); proposes that Hector issue a challenge to Achaeans (7.51); one of the leaders of the assault on the wall (12.97); kills Depyrus (13.687); attacked by Menelaus, is wounded (13.692); cursed by Priam (24.310).
son of Oenops, an Achaean warrior: killed by Hector (5.813).
son of Panthous, Trojan warrior: killed by Menelaus (14.603); mentioned by Menelaus (17.30).
god of the sun: doesn't reach Tartarus (8.564), (14.408); Agamemnon invokes him to swear he has not had sex with Briseis (19.317).

son of Zeus and Alcmene, legendary Greek hero, father of Tlepolemus: story of his capture of Astyocheia (2.733); grandfather of Pheidippus and Antiphus (2.752); wounded Hera with an arrow (5.463); wounded Hades (5.467); praised by his son Tlepolemos (5.742); helped by Athena (8.422); killed men of Pylos (11.782); Sleep tells of how Zeus reacted to mistreatment of him (14.296); his mother loved by Zeus (14.385); Zeus' pain at his mistreatment (15.31); destined for death (18.146); trick played on him at his birth by Hera (19.122 ff); built wall for Poseidon (20.176).

brother of Zeus and Poseidon, god of the dead: wounded by Hercules (5.467); visited by Hercules (8.426); his unrelenting nature (9.193); Althea begs him to kill Meleager (9.717); division of power with his brothers (15.223); frightened by the earthquakes (20.72).

divine son of Zeus and Hera, artisan god, crippled in his legs: intervenes to avoid quarrel between Zeus and Hera (1.641 ff); tells story of being thrown from heaven (1.663); serves wine to the gods (1.670); history of the royal staff he made (2.117); saves Ideus from death (5.26); maker of Diomedes' armour (8.226); made Hera's bedroom (14.201); summons Aphrodite to get love charms (14.224); ambidextrous (14.285); gave Zeus the aegis (15.368); yells at Achaeans, shakes the aegis, putting them to flight (15.379); Thetis visits him to get new weapons for Achilles, his workshop and his robot inventions (18.458 ff); story of how Thetis helped him (18.487); prepares materials and makes the shield (18.583 ff); leaves Olympus to help Achaeans (20.44); opposed by Xanthus in battle (20.85); made five layers on the shield (20.323); Hera appeals to him to help Achilles against the river, he prepares a great fire (21.397); Hera tells him to stop the fire, he does so (21.453).
Trojan warrior: moves up with Asius against the wall (12.146); killed by Leonteus (12.201).
son of Phorbas: killed by Peneleus (14.570).

relation.desc: slave and illegitimate son of Priam

person.note: bastard son of Priam: advises Hector to attack Ajax (11.588); one of the leaders in the attack on the wall (12.95); goes with Hector and others to the centre of the battle (13.936); goes into battle with Hector, killed by Patroclus, fight over his body (16.848 ff).
daughter of Priam, wife of Helicaon: Iris takes on her form to visit Helen (3.135); most beautiful of Hecuba's daughters, meets Hector (6.316).
daughter of Agamemnon (9.176).

con of Coronus, grandson of Caeneus, leader of troops from parts of Thessaly: in catalogue of ships (2.819); defense of the Achaean wall (12.136); kills Hippomachus, Menon, Iamenus, Orestes (12.195 ff); enters iron-throwing contest (23.1030).

son of Priam, Trojan warrior: Apollo takes on his form (20.96); meets Achilles, begs for his life, previous encounter with Achilles, killed by Achilles (21.39 ff); silver bowl given as his ransom (23.920).
father of Pandarus (Trojan warrior): advice to Pandarus (5.225 ff).
son of Creon, Achaean warrior: leads out sentinels (9.103); his companion killed, kills Apisaon (17.441); helps fetch gifts for Achilles (19.296).
son of Antenor, Trojan warrior: killed by Telamonian Ajax (15.608).

son of Asclepius, leader of troops from parts of Thessaly, a healer: in catalogue of ships (2.804); ordered by Talthybius to heal Menelaus, does so (4.236 ff); hit with an arrow from Paris, taken from battle by Nestor (11.569 ff); with Nestor drinKing wine (14.2).
son of Talaus and father of Euryalus.
son of Echius, Achaean warrior: takes Hypsenor back to the ships (13.509); killed by Polydamas (15.399).

Achaean warrior, bastard son of Oleus and Rhene, leader of troops from parts of Thessaly: in catalogue of ships (2.798); fighting against Hector by the ships, details of his past (13.827); killed by Aeneas, details of his past (15.392 ff).
Trojan warrior: encouraged by Hector (17.279).

son of Phyleus, leader of troops from Doulichium (part of Aeachan army): in catalogue of ships (2.703); kills Pedaeus (5.78); fighting against Hector (13.825); collects the best troops to fight Hector (15.360); attacks Polydamas, kills Croesmus, fights Dolops (15.612 ff); kills Amphiclus (16.367); helps fetch gifts for Achilles (19.295).
son of Hicataon, Trojan warrior: criticized by Hector (15.641); killed by Antilochus (15.675).

relation.desc: son of Priam but not Hecuba

person.note: Trojan warrior: killed by Teucer (8.323).
Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.810).
Achaean warrior: helps to fetch presents for Achilles (19.297).

son of Peteos, leader of Athenian soldiers (fighting with the Achaeans): in catalogue of ships (2.629); upbraided by Agamemnon as he prepares for battle (4.383); asks for help to repel Sarpedon's attack, tells Thotes to ask Ajaxes for help (12.359 ff); helps carry body of Amphimachus (13.240); fighting Hector by the ships (13.823).
leader of the Cicones, Trojan warrior: Apollo takes on his form (17.91).

son of Molus, attendant on Idomeneus, part of Cretan contingent in Achaean forces: in catalogue of ships (2.726); preparing for battle (4.297); kills Phereclus (5.66); volunteers to fight Hector (7.200); returns quickly to battle (8.310); leads out the sentinels (9.102); goes to council meeting (10.234); volunteers for spy mission (10.271); helps Odysseus arm for night raid (10.308); encouraged by Poseidon in form of Calchas (13.106); hits Dephobus, spear shatters, withdraws to get another spear (13.185); meets Idomeneus by the huts, gets a spear (13.297 ff); asks Idomeneus where to rejoin the battle (13.370); Idomeneus calls to him for help (13.576); wounds Dephobus in the arm (13.634); kills Adamas (13.677); kills Harpalion (13.776); kills Morus and Hippotion (14.601); collects the best troops to fight Hector (15.360); kills Acamas (16.399); kills Laogonus (16.702); fights Aeneas, boasts aloud, reprimanded by Patroclus (16.709 ff); comes up to help Telamonian Ajax and Menealus over Patroclus' body (17.335); speaks to Idomeneus, saves Coeranus' horses (17.756); given instructions by Menelaus (17.813); helps recover Patroclus' body (17.874 ff); helps fetch gifts for Achilles (19.296); supervises collection of wood for Patroclus' pyre (23.135); enters chariot race (23.429); comes in fourth in the chariot race (23.644); enters the archery contest and wins (23.1058); enters spear-throwing contest (23.1091).
son of Atymnius, Trojan warrior: killed by Antilochus (5.680).
Trojan warrior from Paeonia: killed by Achilles (21.249).
leader of Phrygians (3.203).

relation.desc: one of the favourite maids of Penelope

person.note: father of Imbrius (Trojan warrior).

son of Lycaon, leader of troops from Zeleia (part of Trojan forces): in Trojan display of forces (2.908); Athena persuade him to break the truce by firing at Menelaus (4.105 ff); description of his bow (4.124); hits Diomedes with an arrow (5.107 ff); challenged by Aeneas to shoot Diomedes, tells story of his coming to Troy (5.192 ff); agrees to challenge Diomedes with Aeneas (5.269); challenges and fights Diomedes and is killed (5.349 ff).
a Trojan senior statesman: with Priam at the Scaean Gates, observes Helen (3.161); father of Polydamas (15.522); father of Euphorbus (16.937).
son of Imbrasus, leader of Thracians, part of Achaean forces: kills Diores (4.598); killed by Thoas (4.608).
alleged father of Asteropaeus (21.169).
leader of troops from parts of Thessaly: left on Lemnos before reaching Troy (2.790).
son of Phaenops, leader of Phrygians (Trojan allies): in Trojan display of forces (2.945); encouraged by Hector (17.281); killed by Telamonian Ajax (17.399).
leader of troops from Thessaly (part of Achaean forces): killed while landing at Troy before anyone else (2.771).
son of Priam: Iris takes on his form (2.868); his excellence in running (2.870); helps Dephobus away from the battle (13.640); kills Echius (15.400); cursed by Priam (24.311).
son of Antentor, Trojan warrior: preparing troops for battle (11.61).
a Boeotian warrior with Achaean forces: killed by Acamas (14.555).
leader of Paphlagonian troops (part of Trojan forces): in display of Trojan forces (2.932); killed by Menelaus (5.675).
leader of troops from Paeonia (Trojan allies): in Trojan display of forces (2.929); killed by Patroclus (16.340).
father of Cleitus (Trojan warrior).
father of Schedius (Achaean warrior).
mentioned as an old comrade by Nestor (1.294).
Achaean warrior, famous for his loud voice: Hera takes on his shape (5.896).

son of Capaneus, one of leaders of troops from the Argolid, special comrade of Diomedes: in catalogue of ships (2.641); upbraided by Agamemnon before battle, replies to Agamemnon (4.434 ff); pulls arrow from Diomedes (5.127); advises Diomedes to draw back (5.285); captures Aeneas' horses (5.377); removed from chariot by Athena (5.956); takes Nestor's horses (8.130); Diomedes says he'll stay with him if the army returns (9.57); collects Diomedes' prize in chariot race (23.622).

one of the Achaean heralds: sent by Agamemnon to collect Briseis (1.356 ff); sent by Agamemnon to fetch sacrifical animals (3.132); ordered by Agamemnon to fetch Machaon to heal Menelaus, does so (4.226 ff); helps Agamemnon at a sacrifice (19.327); takes a cauldron from Agamemnon (23.1103).
daughter of Cisseus, wife of Antenor: raises a bastard son, Pedaeus, as her own (5.79); priestess of Athena in Troy (6.374); mother of Iphidamas (11.254).
a common Achaean soldier: insults Agamemnon and is beaten by Odysseus (2.247 ff).

son of Nestor, Achaean warrior: leads out the sentinels (9.100); attends council meeting (10.234); volunteers for spy mission (10.271); gives Diomedes a sword (10.303); Nestor takes his shield (14.11); kills Maris (16.377); position in the battle (17.477); sent by Menelaus to help (17.860); helps fetch gifts for Achilles (19.295).
senior Trojan statesman: with Priam at the Scaean Gates, observing Helen (3.161).

father of Priam, Lampus, Tithonus, Clytius, Hicataon: Anchises gets foals from his herd (5.320); Hercules visits him for his horses (5.745); Apollo and Poseidon built a wall for him (7.529); his family (20.282); harsh treatment of Apollo and Poseidon (21.536).

son of Hercules and Astyocheia, leader of troops from Rhodes, part of Achaean army: in catalogue of ships (2.728); story of his murder of Licymnius (2.731); challenges Sarpedon, fights, and dies (5.733 ff).

divine sea nymph, mother of Achilles, daughter of the old man of the sea: responds to Achilles' prayer for help, visits him (1.396 ff); story of her saving Zeus from other gods (1.439); laments Achilles' fate, offers to seek Zeus help for him (1.460); visits Zeus, ask for help for Achilles (1.551 ff); Athena complains about Zeus' favour to her (8.431); told Achilles his fate (9.516); took in Epeigeus as a suppliant (16.670); doesn't tell Achilles of Patroclus' death (17.511); hears Achilles' cry of grief, leads the lament in the sea (18.44 ff); goes to Achilles (18.79); promises to get armour for Achilles, sends her sisters away, goes to Olympus (18.158 ff); visits Hephaestus to get weapons for Achilles (18.458 ff); helped Hephaestus (18.502); tells Hephaestus Achilles' story, asks for new weapons (18.529); leaves Olympus with armour for Achilles (18.747); gives Achilles the divine armour (19.3 ff); tells Achilles to renounce his anger (19.41); meets Iris who summons her to Zeus, goes to Olympus, hear Zeus' solution to problem of Hector's body (24.103); receives instructions from Zeus, visits Achilles, tells him to accept a ransom (24.128).
a Trojan elder: sitting with Priam and the Scaean Gates, comment on Helen (3.159).
a nymph: mother of Aesepus and Pedasus (Trojan warriors); sex with Bucolion (6.25 ff).
a son of Eurydamas, a Trojan warrior: killed by Diomedes (5.170).
Trojan warrior: killed by Antilochus (6.36).
father of Periboea (mother of Asteropaeus, Trojan warrior) (21.170).
father of Danae (a woman loved by Zeus).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.50).
son of Azeus, father of Astyoche: mentioned (2.589).
father of Echecles.
alleged father of Cteatus and Eurytus, grandfather of Amphimachus: father of two men who beat Nestor in the chariot race (23.789).
son of Pheres, father of Eumelus (an Achaean warrior). (2.787); his fine horses (2.839).
Trojan warrior, son of Merops, leader of troops from the Troad: in list of Trojan forces (2.912), killed by Diomedes (11.375).
Trojan warrior: captured alive by Menelaus, pleads for ransom, killed by Agamemnon (6.43 ff).
Trojan warrior, killed by Patroclus (16.808).
father of Peleus, grandfather of Achilles, son of Zeus: Achilles boasts of him as an ancestor (21.226).
father of Theseus, mentioned by Nestor (1.294).
daughter of Adrestus, wife of Diomedes: (5.490).
Trojan warrior from Paeonia: killed by Achilles (21.250).
father of Alcathous: his tomb as lookout (2.870); father of Alcathous (Trojan warrior) (13.515).
Achaean warrior: killed by Hector (11.343).
daughter of Pittheus, a servant attending on Helen: goes with her to the walls of Troy (3.158).
father of Epeigeus (Achaean warrior).
daughter of Augeias, wife of Mulius: knowledge of medicine (11.848).
son of Augeas, father of Polyxenus (a leader of Epeians).
son of Paeon, Trojan warrior: wounded and killed by Diomedes (11.384).
son of Priam: cursed by Priam (24.310).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.51).
Achaean warrior: killed by Hector (11.343).
people from Euboea (island near Athens), fighting with the Achaeans: in catalogue of ships (2.614).
a tribe from the north of Hellas: Zeus looks away from battle to their land (13.8).
collective name for the forces from Hellas under Agamemnon, used interchangeably with the term Argives or Danaans
Trojan warrior, son of Asius: moves up with Asius against the wall (12.147); attacks Antilochus (13.669); killed by Meriones (13.678).
man whose tomb is an important site in Arcadia: in catalogue of ships (2.682).
those living in Aetolia, an area of north-central Greece, part of the Achaean forces: in catalogue of ships (2.714); their old fight with the Curetes over Calydon (9.662 ff).
mother of Nireus, son of her and Charopus (2.746).
son of Portheus (14.141).
monster with a hundred hands: summoned by Thetis to save Zeus (1.446).
inhabitants of a region of Thessaly: centaurs beaten there (2.817).
one of Hector's horses (8.213).
one of the Achaean warrior leaders serving under Nestor: receives his orders (4.346); helps wounded Teucer (8.388); helps take Hypsenor from the battle (13.509).
Trojan warrior: killed by Odysseus (5.784).
father of Tros (a Trojan warrior).
Trojan warrior: killed by Odysseus (5.785).
daughter of Pelias, mother of Eumelus. (2.787).
son of Laerces, Achaean warrior, leader of one contingent of Myrmidons (16.233); joins Automedon in Achilles' chariot (17.579 ff); gets instructions from Automedon (17.617).
son of Thestor, Achaean warrior: killed by Sarpedon (12.434).
a woman loved by Zeus, mother of Hercules (14.384); birth of Hercules (19.121).
father of Leitus (Achaean warrior).
father of Promachus (Trojan warrior).
father of Otus and Ephialtes.
river in the Peloponnese: father of Orsilochus: near Thryoessa (11.811); site of battle between Epeians and Pylians (11.831); father of Orsilochus (5.644).
father of Laothoe, grandfather of Lycaon, ruler of the Leleges: gave rich dowry with Laothoe (22.65).
mother of Meleager (9.697); begs the gods to kill her son (9.713).
father of Diores (a leader of Epeians); Nestor's achievements at his funeral games (23.777).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.57).
female warriors: in Phrygia (3.206); massacred by Bellerophon (6.239).
father of Atymnius and Maris: reared the Chimera (16.384).
son of Polyaimon, Trojan warrior: killed by Teucer (8.323)
Trojan warrior: killed by Meges (16.368).
man from Cythera: receives cap from Autocylus, gives it to Molus (10.317).
father of man killed by Patroclus long ago (23.105).
leader of Epeians, part of the Achaean contingent, son of Cteatus: in catalogue of ships (2.697); killed by Hector (13.227).
son of Nomion, leader of the Carians (Trojan allies): in the Trojan display of forces: (2.954).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.53).
leader of Epeians (Achaean warrior): (13.826).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.51).
mortal father of Hercules.
Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.484).
son of Ormenus, father of Phoenix (Achaean warrior): Autolycos stole his cap (10.315).
father of Agapenor, an Achaean leader.
an opponent defeated in wrestling by Nestor (23.783).
father of Thoas (leader of Aetolians): home in Pleuron (13.263).
wife of Proetus: hostility to Bellerophon (6.199)
father of Simoeisius (Trojan warrior).
son of Priam: cursed by Priam (24.311).
son of Thessalus, grandson of Hercules, leader of men from many Aegean Islands (part of Achaean army): in catalogue of ships (2.751).
son of Talaemenes and Gygaea, leader of Meonians (allies of the Trojans): in Trojan display of forces (2.947).
son of Priam: kills Leucus (4.567); killed by Agamemnon (11.110).
son of Caletor, Achaean warrior: leads out sentinels (9.102); Idomeneus calls him for assistance (13.575); killed by Aeneas (13.647).
son of Phausius, Trojan warrior: killed by Eurypylus (11.651).
son of Hippasus, Trojan warrior: killed by Lycomedes (17.444).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.54).
inhabitans of Arcadia: their battle with Pylians (7.157).
son of Iphitus, Trojan warrior: Hector makes him his charioteer (8.147); killed by Teucer (8.363).
father of Prothonor (Achaean warrior).
Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.362).
Trojan warrior: killed by Teucer (6.36).
father of Polymelus (Trojan warrior).
monster killed by Hermes
daughter of Minos: a dancing floor constructed for her (18.724).
people living in the region where the monster Typhoeus lies underground (2.861).
a horse belonging to Adrestus (23.423).
father of Leocritus (Achaean warrior).
father of Hecamede.
Achaean warrior: killed by Hector (11.341).
Trojan warrior: goes with Hector and others to centre of the battle (13.938).
father of Podaleirus and Machaon.
son of Tros, father of Capys (father of Anchises): his family line (20.277).

alleged son of Pelagon, son of the river Axius and Periboea, Trojan warrior: one of the leaders of the assault on the wall (12.107); encouraged by Hector (17.280); best of the Paeonians (17.448); tries to assault the Achaeans (17.449); his family line, fights Achilles and is killed (21.168 ff); his breastplate given as consolation prize in the chariot race (23.686); his sword offered as a prize in the hand to hand combat (23.991).
Trojan warrior: killed by Polypoetes (6.34).
Trojan warrior: killed by Diomedes (5.164).
son of Protiaon, Trojan warrior: takes horses for Polydamas (15.534).
mother of Ialmenus and Ascalaphus (Achaean warriors), sons of Ares: her seduction mentioned (2.589).
mother of Tlepolemus (with Hercules): (2.732).
Trojan warrior from Paeonia: killed by Achilles (21.250).

divine daughter of Zeus, responsible for human and divine folly: daughter of Zeus, deluder of gods and men: followed by Prayers (9.630), Agamemnon blames her, tells how she deceived Zeus (19.113 ff); thrown out of Olympus (19.156).
King of Argos, son of Pelops, father of Agamemnon and Menelaus (known as the "sons of Atreus"): receives royal staff from Pelops, passes it on to his brother Thyestes (2.122).
father of Mydon (Trojan warrior).
son of Amisodarus, Trojan warrior: killed by Antilochus (16.373).
King of Elis, father of Agamede, Agasthenes, grandfather of Polyxenus (leader of Epeians): keeps Neleus' horses (11.795); father in law of Mulius (11.847).
stole cap from Amyntor (10.314).
Achaean warrior: killed by Hector (11.341).
Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.809).
father of Polyphontes.
river in Paeonia (in north-eastern Greece), also the river god: in Trojan list of forces (2.930); (16.341); father of Asteropaeus (with Periboea) (21.169).
father of Actor.
son of Chalcon, Achaean warrior: killed by Glaucus (16.691).
son of Glaucus: his story told by descendant Glaucus (his grandson) (6.193).
Trojan warrior: killed by Agamemnon (11.99).

the north wind: Achilles prays to it, Iris delivers the prayer, the wind answers the request (23.234 ff); a god: revives Sarpedon (5.803); (9.5); (14.463); blew Hercules off course (15.31); copulates with horses of Erichthonius (20.266).
father of Phaestus (a Trojan warrior).
son of Perieres, husband of Polydora, passes as father of Menesthius (16.210).
son of Laomedon, father of Pedasus and Aesepus (Trojan warriors): sex with Abarbarea (6.28).
father of Sphelus.
father of Briseis.
citizens of Thebes in Boeotia: Tydeus visits them and competes against them, they try to ambush him (4.451 ff); Tydeus beats them with Athena's help (5.919).
King of Thebes: his sons beaten at the funeral games of Oedipus (23.840).
father of Coronus, grandfather of Leonteus (an Achaean warrior): mentioned by Nestor as an old comrade (1.291).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.55).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.53).
father of Sthenelus (Achaean warrior).
son of Assaracus, father of Anchises (father of Aeneas): his family (20.285).
river from Mount Ida to the sea: stirred up by Apollo or Poseidon to destroy the wall (12.21).
inhabitants of Caria (a region of Asia Minor), allies of the Trojans: in display of Trojan forces (2.951); (4.166); camped beside the sea (10.512).
mother of Gorgythion (son of Priam).
brother of Helen, Achaean warrior: already dead at home (3.261), one of the Dioscouri (with his twin brother, Pollux or Polydeuces).
people of Asia Minor, Trojan allies: encamped by the sea: (10.513); preparing to fight (20.391).
wild creatures, half human, half horse, living on Mt. Pelion: beaten away from Pelion by Peirithos (1.298, 2.816).
father of Troezenus, grandfather of Euphemus (Trojan ally).
troops in Odysseus' contingent (part of Achaean army): in catalogue of ships (2.707).
father of Elephenor (an Achaean warrior) in catalogue of ships (2.613).
father of Bathycles (Achaean warrior).
goddess, wife of Hephaestus: meets Thetis, welcomes her (18.474).
son of Hippasus, brother of Socus, Trojan warrior: killed by Odysseus (11.485).
father of Nireus (Achaean warrior).
Trojan warrior: killed by Odysseus (11.481).
legendary monster: killed by Bellerophon (6.230); raised by Amisodarus (16.385).
a centaur: gave medicines to Asclepius (4.256); gave spear to Peleus (16.174; 19.471).
Trojan warrior: killed by Odysseus (5.784).
one of the leaders of troops from Pylos: receives orders from Nestor (4.346).
son of Priam: killed by Diomedes (5.184).
Trojan warrior: killed by Teucer (8.322).
Trojan warrior: goes with Aeneas and Hector to attack Automedon (17.610); withdraws (17.654).
Trojan ally, leader of Mysians: in Trojan display of forces (2.940).
Trojan warrior: encouraged by Hector (17.281).
daughter of Agamemnon (9.175).
Trojan allies from Thrace: in Trojan display of forces (2.928).
people ruled by Etion: (6.484).
man in Cyprus: gave breast plate to Agamemnon (11.21).
father of Theano: raised Iphidamas, tries to stop Iphidamas going to war (11.255).
son of Peisenor, Trojan warrior: killed by Teucer (15.521).
Trojan warrior: killed by Olean Ajax (16.386).
daughter of Maripessa and Ides, wife of Meleager (9.699); Alcyone: what her parents called Cleopatra (9.707); begs Meleager to defend the city (9.744).
one of Helen's attendants: goes with her to the walls of Troy (3.158).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.55).
wife of Agamemnon: Agamemnon mentions her (1.121).
son of Enops: defeated in boxing by Nestor (23.782).
deity: depicted on Achilles' shield (18.659).
eldest son of Antenor, Trojan warrior: attacks Agamemnon, wounds him, is killed (11.284).
father of Periphetes (Achaean warrior): took messages to Hercules (15.744).

father of Alcestis (mother of Eumeleus). (2.788).
father of Atreus, grandfather of Agamemnon and Menelaus: receives royal staff from Hermes, passes it on to his son Atreus (2.121).

leader of the Boeotians (part of Achaean forces), in catalogue of ships (2.570); encouraged by Poseidon in the form of Calchas (13.105); kills Ilioneus (14.569); kills Lyco (16.391); wounded by Polydamas (17.728).
inhabitants of a region in north-west Greece: in catalogue of ships (2.823).
father of Deicon (Trojan warrior).
daughter of Acessamenus, mother of Asteropaeus: had sex with the river Axius (21.170).
father of Borus.
son of Megas, Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.809).
son of Ochesius, Achaean warrior: killed and stripped by Ares (5.964).
son of Epytos, Trojan herald: Apollo takes his form (17.412).
Trojan warrior: killed by Teucer (14.602).
son of Copreus, Achaean warrior from Mycenae: killed by Hector (15.744).
divine wife of Hades: punishes Phoenix (9.574); Althea begs her to kill Meleager (9.718).
son of Zeus and Dana (14.381).
father of Menestheus, leader of Athenians (2.629).
father of Xanthus and Thon (Trojan warriors): loses his heirs (5.176).
father of Phorcys (Trojan warrior).
son of Asius, Trojan warrior: Apollo takes on his form (17.710).
son of Borus, a Maeonian fighting with the Trojans: killed by Idomeneus (5.48).
Trojan warrior: goes with Hector and others to centre of the battle (13.937); armour stripped by Antilochus (14.600).
father of Apisaon (Trojan warrior).
son of Dares, Trojan warrior: killed by Diomedes (5.12 ff).
Achaean warrior: fighting against Hector (13.824).
son of Thessalus, grandson of Hercules, leader of troops from many Aegean Islands: in catalogue of ships (2.751).
son of Tecton, Trojan warrior: killed by Meriones (5.66); made ships for Paris (5.69).
father of Admetus.
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.52).
father of Demuchus (a Trojan warrior).
people fighting against Ephyreans (13.366).

son of Amyntor, old companion and tutor of Achilles, Achaean warrior: proposed as delegate to Achilles (9.206); visits Achilles with the Achaean delegation (9.222 ff); Achilles proposes he spend the night with him (9.535); responds to Achilles, tells of their special relationship, his family strife, story of Meleager (9.541 ff); stays with Achilles (9.837); leader of a contingent of Myrmidons (16.233); Athena takes on his form (17.677); stays with Achilles to mourn over Patroclus (19.379); set as umpire in the chariot race (23.440).
father of woman loved by Zeus (14.383).
father of Diomede (9.840).
father of Ilioneus (Trojan warrior): rich man, loved by Hermes (14.570).
father of Agelaos (Trojan warrior).
mother of Hyperenor and Euphorbus, wife of Panthous.
Trojan warrior: killed by Leitus (6.41).
father of Iphicles.
father of Meges (leader of troops from Doulichium): anger at his father (2.704); his armour saves his son (15.624); one of Nestor's old opponents, beaten in the spear throw (23.787).
mother of Menesthius (an Achaean warrior).
father of Polymele.
Trojan warrior: killed by Odysseus (6.35).
Hera goes there on the way to Sleep (14.272).
father of Aethrae, one of Helen's attendants: (3.157).
a heavenly consellation: depicted on Achilles' shield (18.603).
son of Asclepius, brother of Machaon, leader of troops from parts of Thessaly (part of Achaean army): in catalogue of ships: (2.804).
son of Iphicles, leader of Thessalians, brother of Protesilaus: in catalogue of ships (2.778); fighting against Hector by the ships (13.827).
a harpy, mother of Achilles' horses (16.181; 19.481).
one of Hector's horses (8.213).
one of Menelaus' horses (23.353).
son of Etion, Trojan warrior: killed by Menelaus (17.700).
brother of Helen: already dead at home (3.261).
father of Amopaon (Trojan warrior).
daughter of Peleus: has sex with the river Sperchius, mother of Menesthius (16.207).
son of Priam and Laothoe, brother of Lycaon: Lycaon tells of his death at hands of Achilles (21.106).
one of Nestor's old opponents, beaten by him in the spear throw (23.787).
son of Priam: killed by Achilles (20.488).
son of Eurydamas, Trojan warrior: killed by Diomedes (5.170).
mother of Eudorus (Achaean warrior): (16.214); sex with Hermes (16.215).
son of Argeas, Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.486).
leader of an expedition against Thebes: visit to Mycenae with Tydeus to raise troops (4.441).
Trojan warrior: goes with Hector and others to the centre of the battle (13.937).
son of Autophonus: leader of Cadmeans in their ambush against Tydeus (4.462).

son of Peirithos and Hippodameia, leader of troops from parts of Thessaly (part of Achaean forces): in catalogue of ships (2.812); kills Astyalus (6.34); defends the Achaean wall (12.135); kills Damaeus, Pylon, Ormenus (12.189); enters the iron-throwing contest, wins first prize (23.1029).
son of Agasthenes, grandson of Augeas, a leader of Epeians (part of Achaean army): in catalogue of ships (2.700).
great-grandfather of Diomedes: his family (14.140).
daughters of Zeus: walk behind Folly (9.628).
ancient King of Argos: hostility to Bellerophon (6.196).
Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.464).
son of Areilycus, one of the Boeotian leaders in the Achaean force: in the catalogue of ships (2.571); killed by Polydamas (14.525).
Trojan warrior: killed by Teucer (14.602).
son of Teuthredon, leader of the Magnetes (part of Achaean forces): in catalogue of ships (2.832).
father of Astynous (Trojan warrior).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.51).
Trojan warrior: killed by Odysseus (5.785).
father of Eurymedon (aide to Agamemnon) (4.265).
son of Lethus, leader of troops from regions near Troy (part of Trojan army): in Trojan display of forces (2.923).
Trojan warrior: killed by Telamonian Ajax (11.554).
Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.811).
residents of Pylos: fight with the Arcadians (7.156); Nestor tells story of their war with Eleans (11.759 ff); given power by Zeus (11.864).
Trojan warrior: killed by Polypoetes (12.194).
Trojan warrior: killed by Telamonian Ajax (11.554).
Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.486).
son of Zeus (14.384).
goddess, wife of Cronos: gave Hera to Oceanus and Tethys (14.243); her three sons with Cronos (15.224).
mother of Medon (illegitimate son of Oileus).
King of a Thracian contingent, Trojan allies: quality of his horses and armour, position in the camp (10.522); sleeping in the middle of his troops (10.567); killed by Diomedes (10.592).
river flowing from Mount Ida to the sea: stirred into action by Poseidon and Apollo (12.20).
son of Peires, Trojan warrior: killed by Achilles (20.582).
river from Mount Ida to the sea: stirred up by Poseidon and Apollo to destroy the wall (12.21).
messenger from Zeus (2.109).
son of Enops and a Naiad nymph, Trojan warrior: killed by Olean Ajax (14.517).
son of Strophius, Trojan warrior: killed by Menelaus (5.54).
see Astyanax.
son of Perimedes, Achaean warrior, commander of Phoceans: in catalogue of ships (2.592); killed by Hector (15.607).
son of Iphitus, Achaean warrior: killed by Hector (17.393).
goddesses who look after the gates of Olympus: (5.855); (8.459); unyoke Hera's horses (8.505).
father of Amphius (Trojan warrior).
King of Lyrnessus, father of Euneus, grandfather of Mynes and Epistrophus.
priests of Zeus at Dodona (16.279).
a woman loved by Zeus, mother of Dionysus (14.386).

river near Troy: provides ambrosia for Hera's horses (5.889); stirred up by Poseidon and Apollo to destroy the wall (12.22); Ares moves along there encouraging Trojans (20.64); Scamander appeals to him for help against Achilles (21.371).
son of Anthemion, Trojan warrior: killed by Telamonian Ajax (4.549 ff).
son of Aeolus, father Glaucus: lived in Ephyra (6.191).

god, brother of death: Hera visits him on Lemnos, offers him a bride, he agrees to put Zeus to sleep (14.277 ff); goes to Ida, sits in a tree as a bird (14.335 ff); returns to the army to tell Poseidon Zeus is sleeping (14.419); deals with Sarpedon's body (16.794).
son of Hippasus, Trojan warrior: challenges Odysseus, fights him, is killed (11.486).
tribe in Lycia: attacked by Bellerophon (6.237).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.49).
river, father of Menesthius, after copulating with Polydora (16.206); Achilles prays to the river (23.170).
son of Bucolus, father of Iasus.
son of Ithaemenes, Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.682).
son of Perseus, father of Eurystheus (19.152).
Achaean warrior: carries off Amphimachus (13.241); fighting against Hector (13.824); killed by Hector (15.389).
father of Scamandrius (a Trojan warrior).
father of Mesthles and Antiphus (allies of the Trojans).
father of Mecisteus and grandfather of Euryalus.
son of Harmon, father of Phereclus (Trojan warrior).
father of the Greater Ajax and Teucer, both important Achaean warriors: father who cared for Teucer (8.331).
son of Ares, divine presence active in battle: accompanies Ares and Athena into battle (4.513); depicted on Agamemnon's shield (11.38); (13.362); told to get Ares' horses ready (15.143).
wife of Oceanus: raised Hera (14.242, 357).
father of Lethus, grandfather of Hippothous and Pylaeus (Trojan warriors).
father of Axylus.
Achaean warrior: killed by Hector (5.811).
father of Prothous (Achaean warrior).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.48).
son of Eurytus, descendant of Actor, a leader of Epeians, part of the Achaean forces: in catalogue of ships (2.697).
father of Echepolus (Trojan warrior).
singer from Thrace: punishment by the Muses (2.671).
father of Eniopeus (Trojan warrior).
goddess: hands Hera her cup, talks to her (15.106); asked by Zeus to call gods to assembly (20.6).
Trojan warrior from Paeonia: encouraged by Hector (17.280); killed by Achilles (21.249).
son of Aegeus, mentioned by Nestor as an old comrade (1.294).
father of Pheidippus and Antiphus (leaders of troops from Aegean Islands).
father of the prophet Calchas (1.74).
father of the Achaean warrior Alcmaon.
son of Enops, Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.467).

son of Andraemon, leader of Aetolians (part of Achaean army): in catalogue of ships (2.714); kills Peirous ; volunteers to fight Hector (7.201); encouraged by Poseidon in form of Calchas (13.105); Poseidon takes on his form (13.262); sees restored Hector, proposes the best men remain in battle and the rest go back to the ships (15.336); helps fetch gifts for Achilles (19.296).
King of Lemnos: (14.276); received gift of a fine silver bowl (23.919).
Trojan warrior: killed by Menelaus (16.365).
a Nereid (daughter of Nereus): laments with her sisters (18.49).
son of Phaenops, Trojan warrior: killed by Diomedes (5.174).
Trojan warrior: killed by Odysseus (11.481).
Trojan warrior: comes up with Asius to assault the wall (12.146); killed by Antilochus (13.652).
Achaean herald: asked by Menestheus to get help from Ajaxes, does so (12.371).
inhabitants of Thrace, allies of the Trojans: in Trojan display of forces (2.925); new arrivals in the camp (10.521).
Trojan warrior from Paeonia: killed by Achilles (21.250).
Trojan warrior, companion of Sarpedon: killed by Patroclus (16.542).
brother of Atreus, thus uncle of Agamemnon and Menelaus, not a character in the Iliad: receives royal staff from Atreus, passes it on to Agamemnon (2.123).
Trojan warrior: killed by Diomedes (11.364).
gods imprisoned by Zeus in Tartarus (14.331).
lover of Dawn (11.1); son of Laomedon (20.283).
son of Damastor, Trojan warrior: killed by Patroclus (16.485).
Achaean warrior: killed by Hector (5.812).
father of Euphemus (Trojan ally), son of Ceos.
son of Priam: mentioned by Priam (24.320).

inhabitants of Troy (thus separate from their allies): march out in formation (3.2); pray that the truce will hold (3.333, 355); their hatred for Paris (3.510); sense the gods will break the truce (4.98); move to battle in a confusion of languages (4.506); rallied by Ares (5.549); go out to collect their dead (7.490); move out against Achaeans (8.63); given renewed force by Zeus (8.391); prepare a feast and sacrifice in the plain (8.639); Dolon reveals their arrangement in camp (10.499); pushed back to city by Agamemnon (11.173 ff); advanced against Odysseus (11.471); organize themselves to attack the wall (12.89); charge the Achaeans by the wall (12.110); attempts to undermine the wall (12.274); following Hector to attack the ships (13.42); advance against Achaeans inside the wall (13.160); charge Achaeans en masse (13.401); attack Achaeans in close formation (13.946); retreat from the ships (15.1); Zeus foretells the future of the war (15.74 ff); attack Achaeans (15.364); fight their way to the ships (15.453); attack the ships (15.693); driven back from the ships (16.346); response to Sarpedon's death (16.638); charge Ajax guarding the body of Patroclus (17.301); charge Achaeans again over body of Patroclus (17.339); encourage each other over Patroclus' body (17.526); terrifed by Achilles shout (18.275); hold assembly to decide what to do (18.299 ff); reject Polydamas' advice (18.388); escape Achilles into the city (21.729); reaction to sight of dead Hector (22.508); rush out to see Priam returning with Hector (24.873); collect wood for Hector's pyre, give him funeral rites (24.964).
son of Alastor, Trojan warrior: killed by Achilles (20.555).

son of Erichthonius, father of Ilus, Assaracus, Ganymede, earlier King of Troy, ancestor of Priam, father of Ganymede: quality of his horses giiven as payment from Zeus for Ganymede (5.314); his story told by Aeneas (20.275).
maker of Ajax's shield (7.261).

father of Diomedes: story of his achievements (4.436); achieves retold by Athena (5.913); killed at Thebes (6.282); Diomedes invokes him in prayer to Athena (10.339); Diomedes speaks of him (14.138 ff).
fabulous monster held captive underground by Zeus: Achaean army compared to T. (2.861).

the west wind: Achilles prays to it for help, Iris delivers his message, he complies (23.235 ff); (2.173); whips up the sea (9.5); conceived Achilles' horses with Podarge (16.182); Iris delivers a message to the winds at his home (23.241).

revisionDesc.change: Created file with a few pages from Wikipedia
